criteria: Accuracy in identifying the unknown number
Understanding of the relationship between multiplication and division
Ability to apply knowledge to different contexts
descriptions: Does not attempt to solve or provides an answer that is completely unrelated to the equation.
Attempts to solve the equation but arrives at an incorrect answer due to a misunderstanding of the operation.
Solves simple multiplication or division equations but struggles with more complex problems or those involving larger numbers.
Generally solves multiplication and division equations accurately, but makes occasional errors.
Consistently solves multiplication and division equations accurately, demonstrating a strong understanding of the relationship between the three numbers.
Solves multiplication and division equations accurately and efficiently, and can explain the reasoning behind the solution.
Shows no understanding of the inverse relationship between multiplication and division.
Demonstrates a limited understanding of the relationship, struggling to apply it in problem-solving.
Understands that multiplication and division are related but has difficulty using this understanding to find the unknown number.
Can explain the relationship between multiplication and division and use it to solve some equations.
Clearly explains and applies the inverse relationship between multiplication and division to solve equations efficiently.
Demonstrates a deep understanding of the multiplicative relationship and can apply it to solve complex problems or explain mathematical concepts.
Unable to apply the concept to different equation structures or real-world scenarios.
Struggles to apply the concept to equations that are presented in a different format.
Can solve standard equations but struggles when the unknown number is in a different position.
Solves equations with the unknown number in various positions and in simple word problems.
Solves equations accurately in various contexts, including word problems, demonstrating strong application skills.
Applies the concept to complex scenarios, including multi-step problems, and can create their own equations.
